His head. "I wasn't really that hungry. I wanted to help my mom, but that's not the main reason. Please don't make me suffer, Sonia."

Sonia put her hands together. "Could it really be true? Oh my God, what a truth! Who would believe it? How could you give away your last bit of money and still rob and kill? Oh," she suddenly exclaimed, "that money you gave to Katerina Ivanovna… that money… could it be…?"

"No, Sonia," he interrupted quickly, "that money wasn’t it. Don't worry! That money was sent to me by my mother when I was sick, the day I gave it to you. Razumihin saw it; he got it for me. That money was mine—my own."

Sonia listened, confused, and tried her best to understand. "And that money… I don’t even really know if there was any money," he said quietly, thinking. "I took a purse off her neck, made of soft leather, full of something… but I didn’t look inside; I guess I didn’t have time. And the things—chains and trinkets—I buried under a stone with the purse the next morning in a yard off V—— Prospect. They’re still there now."

Sonia focused hard to listen. "Then why… you said you did it to rob, but you took nothing?" she asked quickly, hoping for an answer. 

"I don’t know… I haven’t decided yet whether to take that money or not," he said, thinking again, then suddenly giving a short, ironic smile. "Oh, what silly thoughts."

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov struggles with the moral implications of his crime, revealing his inner turmoil and confusion about his motivations.
